div1.head:
TO THE
READER.
div1.p:
This Book was ju&longs;t fini&longs;hed, and de&longs;igned for the Pre&longs;s, when the Author, to the great lo&longs;s of the Learned World, was &longs;eized by a Di&longs;ea&longs;e that brought him to his Death. However he took care in his la&longs;t Will of its Publication, de&longs;iring his Brother, to whom it was writ, to take that Trouble upon him. But he was &longs;o taken up with Bu&longs;ine&longs;s and Removals, (as being Secretary in Holland to the King of Great Britain) that he could find no time for it till a Year after the Death of the Author: When it &longs;o fell out, that the Printers being &longs;omewhat tardy, and this Gentleman dying, the Book was left without either Father or Guardian. Yet it
now ventures into the Publick, in the &longs;ame Method that it was writ by the Author, and with the &longs;ame In&longs;cription to his Brother, tho' dead; in confidence that this la&longs;t Piece of his will meet with as kind a Reception from the World as all the other Works of that Author have. 'Tis true there are not every where Mathematical Demon&longs;trations; but where they are wanting, you have probable and ingenious Conjectures, which is the mo&longs;t that can be rea&longs;onably expected in &longs;uch matters. What belongs to, or has any thing to do with A&longs;tronomy, you will &longs;ee demon&longs;trated, and the re&longs;t ingeniou&longs;ly and &longs;hrewdly gue&longs;s'd at, from the Affinity and Relation of the heavenly Bodies to the Earth. For your farther Satisfaction read on, and farewel.
THE
PUBLISHER
TO THE
READER.
I Doubt not but I &longs;hall incur the Cen&longs;ures of learned Men for putting this Book into Engli&longs;h, becau&longs;e, they'll &longs;ay, it renders Philo&longs;ophy cheap and vulgar, and, which is wor&longs;e, furni&longs;hes a &longs;ort of injudicious People with a &longs;mattering of Notions, which being not able to make a proper u&longs;e of, they pervert to the Injury of Religion and Science. I confe&longs;s the Allegation is too true: but after Bi&longs;hop Wilkins, Dr. Burnet, Mr. Whi&longs;ton and others, to &longs;ay nothing of the ancient Philo&longs;ophers, who wrote in their own
Tongues; I &longs;ay, after the&longs;e great Authors have treated on as learned and ab&longs;tru&longs;e Subjects in the &longs;ame Language, I hope their Example will be allowed a &longs;ufficient excu&longs;e for printing this Book in Engli&longs;h.
Concerning this Edition I can &longs;ay, that I have taken care to have the Cutts exactly done, and have placed each Figure at the Page of the Book that refers to it, which I take to be more convenient to the Reader than putting them all at the End.
I have been careful to procure the be&longs;t Paper, that I might in &longs;ome mea&longs;ure come up to the Beauty of the Latin Edition, though this bear but half the Price of it.
And I hope the Tran&longs;lator has expre&longs;&longs;ed the Author's Sen&longs;e aright, and has not committed Faults beyond what an ingenuous Reader can pardon.

div1.head:
NEW
CONJECTURES
Concerning the
Planetary Worlds,
THEIR
INHABITANTS
AND
PRODUCTIONS.
div1.byline:
Written by Christianus Huygens,
and in&longs;cribed to his Brother
Constantine Huygens.
div1.head: BOOK the Fir&longs;t.
div1.p:
A Man that is of Copernicus's Opinion, that this Earth of ours is a Planet, carry'd round and enlighten'd by the Sun, like the re&longs;t of the Planets, cannot but &longs;ometimes think, that it's
not improbable that the re&longs;t of the Planets have their Dre&longs;s and Furniture, and perhaps their Inhabitants too as well as this Earth of ours: E&longs;pecially if he con&longs;iders the later Di&longs;coveries made in the Heavens &longs;ince Copernicus's time, viz. the Attendants of Jupiter and Saturn, and the champaign and hilly Countries in the Moon, which are a &longs;trong Argument of a Relation and Kin between our Earth and them, as well as a Proof of the Truth of that Sy&longs;tem. This has often been our Talk, I remember, good Brother, over a large Tele&longs;cope, when we have been viewing tho&longs;e Bodies, a Study that your continual Bu&longs;ine&longs;s and Ab&longs;ence have interrupted for many Years. But we were always apt to conclude, that 'twas in vain to enquire after what Nature is doing there, &longs;eeing there was no likelihood of ever coming to any Certainty of the Enquiry. Nor could I ever find that any Philo&longs;ophers, either antient or modern, have attempted any thing upon this Subject. At the very Birth
of A&longs;tronomy, when the Earth was fir&longs;t a&longs;&longs;erted to be Spherical, and to Some have already talk'd of the Inhabitants of the Planets, but went no farther. be &longs;urrounded with Air, even then there were &longs;ome Men &longs;o bold as to affirm, there were an innumerable Company of Worlds in the Stars. But later Authors, &longs;uch as Cardinal Cu&longs;anus, Brunus, Kepler, (and if we may believe him, Tycho was of that opinion too) have furni&longs;hed the Planets with Inhabitants. Nay, Cu&longs;anus and Brunus have allowed the Sun and fixed Stars theirs too. But this was the utmo&longs;t of their Boldne&longs;s; nor has the ingenious French Author of the Dialogues about the Plurality of Worlds carried this Matter any farther. Only &longs;ome of them have coined &longs;ome Stories of the Men in the Moon, ju&longs;t as probable as Lucian's true Hi&longs;tory; among which I mu&longs;t count Kepler's, which he has diverted us with in his A&longs;tronomical Dream. But a while ago thinking &longs;omewhat &longs;eriou&longs;ly of this matter (not that I count my &longs;elf quicker-&longs;ighted than tho&longs;e great Men, but that I had the Happine&longs;s to live after
mo&longs;t of them) the Enquiry appeared not &longs;o impracticable, nor the Way &longs;o &longs;topt up with Difficulties, but that there was very good room left for probable Conjectures. As they came into my Head, I put them down into common Places, and &longs;hall now try to dige&longs;t them into &longs;ome Method for your better Conception of them, and add &longs;omewhat of the Sun and fix'd Stars, and the Extent of that Univer&longs;e of which our Earth is but an incon&longs;iderable Point. I know you have &longs;uch an E&longs;teem and Reverence for any thing that belongs to the Heavens, that I per&longs;wade my &longs;elf you will read what I have written with &longs;ome Plea&longs;ure: I'm &longs;ure I writ it with a great deal; but as often before, &longs;o now, I find the Saying of Archytas true, even to the Letter, That tho' a Man were admitted into Heaven to view the wonderful Fabrick of the World, and the Beauty of the Stars, yet what would otherwi&longs;e be Rapture and Exta&longs;ie, would be but a melancholy Amazement if he had not a Friend to communicate
it to. I could wi&longs;h indeed that all the World might not be my Judges, but that I might chu&longs;e my Readers, Men like you, not ignorant in A&longs;tronomy and true Philo&longs;ophy; for with &longs;uch I might promi&longs;e my &longs;elf a favourable hearing, and not need to make an Apology for daring to vent any thing new to the World. But becau&longs;e I am aware what weak Hands it's likely to fall into, and what a &longs;evere Sentence I may expect from tho&longs;e who&longs;e Ignorance or Zeal is too great; it may be worth the while to guard my &longs;elf beforehand again&longs;t the A&longs;&longs;aults of tho&longs;e &longs;ort of People.
The Objections of ignorant Cavillers prevented. There's one &longs;ort who knowing nothing of Geometry or Mathematicks, will laugh at it as a whim&longs;ical and ridiculous Undertaking. It's an incredible Thing to them to talk of mea&longs;uring the Di&longs;tance and Magnitude of the Stars: And for the Motion of the Earth, they count it, if not a fal&longs;e, at lea&longs;t a precarious Opinion; and no wonder then if they take what's built upon &longs;uch a &longs;lippery Foundation
for the Dreams of a fanciful Head and a di&longs;temper'd Brain. What &longs;hould we an&longs;wer to the&longs;e Men, but that their Ignorance is the Cau&longs;e of their Di&longs;like, and that if they had &longs;tudied the&longs;e things more, and viewed the Works of Nature nicely, they would have fewer Scruples? But few People having had an opportunity of pro&longs;ecuting the&longs;e Studies, either for want of Parts, Learning or Lei&longs;ure, we cannot blame their Ignorance; and if they re&longs;olve to find fault with us for &longs;pending time in &longs;uch Matters, becau&longs;e they do not under&longs;tand the U&longs;e of them, we mu&longs;t appeal to properer Judges.
The&longs;e Conjectures do not contradict the holy Scriptures. The other &longs;ort, When they hear us talk of new Lands, and Animals, and Creatures endued with as much Rea&longs;on as them&longs;elves, will be ready to cry out, that we &longs;et up our Conjectures again&longs;t the Word of God, and broach Opinions directly oppo&longs;ite to Holy Writ. For we do not there read any thing of the Production of &longs;uch Creatures, no not &longs;o much as that they exi&longs;t; nay rather we
read the quite contrary. For, That only mentions this Earth with its Animals and Plants, and Man the Lord of them: To &longs;uch Per&longs;ons I an&longs;wer, what has been often urged by others before me: That it's evident, God had no de&longs;ign to make a particular Enumeration in the Holy Scriptures, of all the Works of his Creation. When therefore it is plain that under the general Name of Stars or Earth at the Creation, are comprehended all the Heavenly Bodies, even the Attendants upon Jupiter and Saturn, why mu&longs;t all that Multitude of Beings which the Almighty Creator has been plea&longs;ed to place upon them, be excluded the Privilege, and not &longs;uffered to have a Share in the Expre&longs;&longs;ion? And the&longs;e Men them&longs;elves can't but know in what Sen&longs;e it is that all things are &longs;aid to be made for the U&longs;e of Man, not certainly for us to look at through a Tele&longs;cope, for that's very ab&longs;urd. Since then the greate&longs;t part of God's Creation, that innumerable multitude of Stars, is placed out of the
reach of any Man's Eye; and many of them it's likely, of the be&longs;t Gla&longs;&longs;es, &longs;o that they don't &longs;eem to belong to us; is it &longs;uch an unrea&longs;onable Opinion to think, that there are &longs;ome rea&longs;onable Creatures who &longs;ee and admire tho&longs;e glorious Bodies at a nearer di&longs;tance?
This Enquiry not over curious. But perhaps they'll &longs;ay, it does not become us to be &longs;o curious and inqui&longs;itive in the&longs;e Things which the Supreme Creator &longs;eems to have kept for his own Knowledge: For &longs;ince he has not been plea&longs;ed to make any farther Di&longs;covery or Revelation of them, it &longs;eems little better than pre&longs;umption to make any inquiry into that which he has thought fit to hide. But the&longs;e Gentlemen mu&longs;t be told, that they take too much upon them&longs;elves when they pretend to appoint how far and no farther Men &longs;hall go in their Searches, and to &longs;et bounds to other Mens Indu&longs;try; as if they knew the Marks that God has placed to Knowledge: or as if Men were able to pa&longs;s tho&longs;e Marks. If our Forefathers had been at this rate &longs;crupulous, we might
have been ignorant &longs;till of the Magnitude and Figure of the Earth, or that there was &longs;uch a Place as America. We &longs;hould not have known that the Moon is inlightned by the Sun's Rays, nor what the Cau&longs;es of the Eclip&longs;es of each of them are, nor a multitude of other Things brought to light by the late Di&longs;coveries in A&longs;tronomy. For what can a Man imagine more ab&longs;tru&longs;e, or le&longs;s likely to be known, than what is now as clear as the Sun? Whence it follows, that vigorous Indu&longs;try, and piercing Wit were given Men to make Advances in the Search of Nature, and there's no Rea&longs;on to put any Stop to &longs;uch Enquiries. I mu&longs;t acknowledge that what I here intend to treat of is not of that Nature as to admit of a certain Knowledge; I can't pretend to a&longs;&longs;ert any thing as po&longs;itively true (for how is it po&longs;&longs;ible) but only to advance a probable Gue&longs;s, the Truth of which every one is at his own liberty to examine. If any one therefore &longs;hall gravely tell me, that I have &longs;pent my Time idly in a vain and fruitle&longs;s Enquiry
after what by my own acknowledgment I can never come to be &longs;ure of; The An&longs;wer is, that at this rate he would put down all Natural Philo&longs;ophy as far as it concerns it &longs;elf in &longs;earching into the Nature Conjectures not u&longs;ele&longs;s, becau&longs;e not certain. of Things: In &longs;uch noble and &longs;ublime Studies as the&longs;e, 'tis a Glory to arrive at Probability, and the Search it &longs;elf rewards the Pains. But there are many degrees of Probable, &longs;ome nearer Truth than others, in the determining of which lies the chief exerci&longs;e The&longs;e Studies u&longs;eful to Religion. of our Judgment. But be&longs;ides the Noblene&longs;s and Plea&longs;ure of the Studies, may not we be &longs;o bold as to &longs;ay, they are no &longs;mall help to the Advancement of Wi&longs;dom and Morality? &longs;o far are they from being of no u&longs;e at all. For here we may mount from this dull Earth, and viewing it from on high, con&longs;ider whether Nature has laid out all her Co&longs;t and Finery upon this &longs;mall Speck of Dirt. So, like Travellers into other di&longs;tant Countries, we &longs;hall be better able to judge of what's done at home, know how to make a true E&longs;timate of, and &longs;et
its own Value upon every Thing. We &longs;hall be le&longs;s apt to admire what this World calls Great, &longs;hall nobly de&longs;pi&longs;e tho&longs;e Trifles the generality of Men &longs;et their Affections on, when we know that there are a multitude of &longs;uch Earths inhabited and adorned as well as our own. And we &longs;hall wor&longs;hip and reverence that God the Maker of all the&longs;e things; we &longs;hall admire and adore his Providence and wonderful Wi&longs;dom which is di&longs;played and manife&longs;ted all over the Univer&longs;e, to the Confu&longs;ion of tho&longs;e who would have the Earth and all things formed by the &longs;huffling Concour&longs;e of Atoms, or to be without beginning. But to come to our Purpo&longs;e.
Fig. 1 SYSTEMA COPERNICI.
p. 11.
Copernicus's Sy&longs;tem explained. And now becau&longs;e the chief Argument for the Proof of what we intend will be taken from the Di&longs;po&longs;ition of the Planets, among which without doubt, the Earth mu&longs;t be counted in the Copernican Sy&longs;tem, I &longs;hall here fir&longs;t of all draw two Figures. The fir&longs;t is a De&longs;cription of
the Orbs the Planets move in, in that order that they are placed round the Sun, drawn as near as can be in their true Proportions, like what you have &longs;een in my Clock at home. The &longs;econd &longs;hows the Proportions of their Magnitudes in re&longs;pect of one another and of the Sun, which you know is upon that &longs;ame Clock of mine too. In the fir&longs;t the middle Point or Center is the Place of the Sun, round which, in an order that every one knows, are the Orbits of Mercury, Venus, the Earth with that of the Moon about it; then tho&longs;e of Mars, Jupiter and Saturn: and about the two la&longs;t the &longs;mall Circles that their Attendants move in: about Jupiter four, and about Saturn five. Which Circles as well as that of the Moon are drawn larger than their true Proportion would admit, otherwi&longs;e they could not have been &longs;een. You may ea&longs;ily apprehend the Va&longs;tne&longs;s of the&longs;e Orbits by this, that the di&longs;tance of the Earth from the Sun is ten or twelve thou&longs;and of the Earth's Diameters. Almo&longs;t all the&longs;e Circles are in the &longs;ame Plane, declining very
little from that in which the Earth moves, call'd The Plane of the Ecliptick. This Plane is cut obliquely by the Axis upon which the Earth turns it &longs;elf round with re&longs;pect to the Sun in 24 Hours, whence ari&longs;e the Succe&longs;&longs;ions of Day and Night: The Axis of the Earth always keeping the &longs;ame Inclination to the Ecliptick (except a &longs;mall Change be&longs;t known to A&longs;tronomers) while the Earth it&longs;elf is carried in its yearly Cour&longs;e round the Sun, cau&longs;es the regular Order of the Sea&longs;ons of the Year: as you may &longs;ee in all A&longs;tronomers Books. Out of which I &longs;hall tran&longs;cribe hither the Periods of the Revolutions of the Planets, viz. Saturn moves round the Sun in 29 Years, 174 Days, and 5 Hours: Jupiter fini&longs;hes his Cour&longs;e in 11 Years, 317 Days, and 15 Hours: Mars his in about 687 Days. Our Year is 365 Days 6 Hours: Venus's 224 Days 18 Hours: and Mercury's 88 Days. This is the now commonly received Sy&longs;tem, invented by Copernicus, and very agreeable to that frugal Simplicity Nature &longs;hows in all
Arguments for the Truth on't. her Works. If any one is re&longs;olved to find fault with it, let him fir&longs;t be &longs;ure he under&longs;tands it. Let him fir&longs;t &longs;ee in the Books of A&longs;tronomers with how much greater Ea&longs;e and Plainne&longs;s all the Motions of the Stars, and Appearances in the Heavens are explained and demon&longs;trated in this than either in that of Ptolomy or Tycho. Let him con&longs;ider that Di&longs;covery of Kepler, that the Di&longs;tances of the Planets from the Sun, as well of the Earth as the re&longs;t, are in a fix'd certain proportion to the Times they &longs;pend in their Revolutions. Which Proportion it's &longs;ince ob&longs;erved that their Satellites keep round Jupiter and Saturn. Let him examine what a contradictory Motion they are fain to invent for the Solution of the Polar Star's changing its Di&longs;tance from the Pole. For that Star in the end of the little Bear's Tail which now de&longs;cribes &longs;o &longs;mall a Circle round the Pole, that it is not above two Degrees and twenty Minutes, was ob&longs;erved about 1820 Years ago, in the Time of Hipparchus, to be above 12:
and will within a few Ages more be 45 Degrees di&longs;tant from it: and after 25000 Years more will return to the &longs;ame Place it is now in. Now if with them we allow the Heavens to be turned upon their own Axis, at this rate they mu&longs;t have a new Axis every Day: a Thing mo&longs;t ab&longs;urd, and repugnant to the Nature of all Motion. Whereas nothing is ea&longs;ier with Copernicus than to give us Satisfaction in this Matter. Then he may impartially weigh tho&longs;e An&longs;wers that Galilæus, Ga&longs;&longs;endus, Kepler, and others have given to all Objections propo&longs;ed, which have &longs;o &longs;atisfied all Scruples, that generally all A&longs;tronomers now-a-days are brought over to our Side, and allow the Earth its Motion and Place among the Planets. If he cannot be &longs;atisfied with all this, he is either one who&longs;e Dulne&longs;s can't comprehend it, or who has his Belief at another Man's Di&longs;po&longs;al.
Fig. 2.
p. 15.
In the other Figure you have the Globes of the Planets, and of the Sun, repre&longs;ented to your Eyes as placed near one another. Where
The Proportion of the Magnitude of the Planets, in re&longs;pect of one another, and the Sun. I have ob&longs;erved the &longs;ame Proportion, of their Diameters to that of the Sun, that I publi&longs;hed to the World in my Book of The Appearances of Saturn: namely, the Diameter of the Ring round Saturn is to that of the Sun as 11 as to 37; that of Saturn him&longs;elf about as 5 to 37; that of Jupiter as 2 to 11; that of Mars as 1 to 166; of the Earth as 1 to 111; and of Venus as 1 to 84: to which I &longs;hall now add that of Mercury ob&longs;erved by Hevelius in the Year 1661, but calculated by my &longs;elf, and found to be as 1 to 290.
If you would know the way that we came to this Knowledge of their Magnitudes, by knowing the Proportion of their Di&longs;tances from the Sun, and the Mea&longs;ures of their Diameters, you may find it in the Book before-mentioned: And I cannot yet &longs;ee any Rea&longs;on to make an Alteration in tho&longs;e I then &longs;ettled, altho' I will not &longs;ay they are without their Faults. The Lamellæ more convenient than Micrometers. For I can't yet be of their Mind, who think the U&longs;e of Micrometers, as they call them, is beyond that of
our Plates, but mu&longs;t &longs;till think that tho&longs;e thin Plates or Rods of which I there taught the U&longs;e, not to detract from the due Prai&longs;es of &longs;o u&longs;eful an Invention, are more convenient than the Micrometers.
In this proportion of the Planets it is worth while to take notice of the prodigious Magnitude of the Sun in compari&longs;on with the four innermo&longs;t, which are far le&longs;s than Jupiter and Saturn. And 'tis remarkable, that the Bodies of the Planets do not increa&longs;e together with their Di&longs;tances from the Sun, but that Venus is much bigger than Mars.
The Earth ju&longs;tly likened to the Planets, and the Planets to it. Having thus explained the two Schemes, there's no Body I &longs;uppo&longs;e but &longs;ees, that in the fir&longs;t the Earth is made to be of the &longs;ame &longs;ort with the re&longs;t of the Planets. For the very Po&longs;ition of the Circles &longs;hows it. And that the other Planets are round like it, and like it receive all the Light they have from the Sun, there's no room (&longs;ince the Di&longs;coveries made by Tele&longs;copes) to doubt. Another Thing they are like it in is, that they are moved
round their own Axis; for &longs;ince 'tis certain that Jupiter and Saturn are, who can doubt it of the others? Again, as the Earth has its Moon moving round it, &longs;o Jupiter and Saturn have theirs. Now &longs;ince in &longs;o many Things they thus agree, what can be more probable than that in others they agree too; and that the other Planets are as beautiful and as well &longs;tock'd with Inhabitants as the Earth? Or what &longs;hadow of Rea&longs;on can there be why they &longs;hould not?
If any one &longs;hould be at the Di&longs;&longs;ection of a Dog, and be there &longs;hewn the Intrails, the Heart, Stomach, Liver, Lungs and Guts, all the Veins, Arteries and Nerves; could &longs;uch a Man rea&longs;onably doubt whether there were the &longs;ame Contexture and Variety of Parts in a Bullock, Hog, or any other Bea&longs;t, tho' he had never chanc'd to &longs;ee the like opening of them? I don't believe he would. Or were we thoroughly &longs;atisfy'd in the Nature of one of the Moons round Jupiter, &longs;hould not we &longs;traight conclude the &longs;ame of the re&longs;t of them? So if we could be
a&longs;&longs;ur'd in but one Comet, what it was that is the Cau&longs;e of that &longs;trange Appearance, &longs;hould we not make that a Standard to judge of all others by? Arguments from their Similitude, of no &longs;mall weight. 'Tis therefore an Argument of no &longs;mall Weight that is fetch'd from Relation and Likene&longs;s; and to rea&longs;on from what we &longs;ee and are &longs;ure of, to what we cannot, is no fal&longs;e Logick. This mu&longs;t be our Method in this Treati&longs;e, wherein from the Nature and Circum&longs;tances of that Planet which we &longs;ee before our Eyes, we may gue&longs;s at tho&longs;e that are farther di&longs;tant from us.
The Planets are &longs;olid, and not without Gravity. And, Fir&longs;t, 'tis more than probable that the Bodies of the Planets are &longs;olid like that of our Earth, and that they don't want what we call Gravity, that Virtue, which like a Load&longs;tone attracts what&longs;oever is near the Body to its Center. And that they have &longs;uch a Quality, their very Figure is a Proof; for their Roundne&longs;s proceeds only from an equal pre&longs;&longs;ure of all their Parts tending to the &longs;ame Center. Nay more, we are &longs;o skilful now-a-days, as to be able to tell how
much more or le&longs;s the Gravitation in Jupiter or Saturn is than here; of which Di&longs;covery and its Author you may read my E&longs;&longs;ay of the Cau&longs;es of Gravitation.
But now to carry the Search farther, let us &longs;ee by what Steps we mu&longs;t ri&longs;e to the attaining &longs;ome knowledge in the deeper Secrets concerning the State and Furniture of the&longs;e new Earths. They have Sen&longs;es. but &longs;ee that Bodies &longs;o va&longs;tly remote could not be perceived by us in their proper Figures and ju&longs;t Di&longs;tances, any other way than by Sight. There are &longs;ome other things to be con&longs;ider'd fir&longs;t, in which it's probable they have &longs;ome relation to us. Body. But be it what it will, there are many Arguments for their not being without it. But I would have them to know, that all I have &longs;aid of their Knowledge in A&longs;tronomy, has Proofs enough, antecedent to tho&longs;e we now produced. For &longs;uppo&longs;ing the Earth, as we did, one of the Planets of equal Dignity and Honour with the re&longs;t, who would venture to &longs;ay, that no where el&longs;e were to be found any that
enjoy'd the glorious Sight of Nature's Theatre? Or if there were any Fellow-Spectators, yet we were the only ones that had dived deep into the Secrets and Knowledge of it? So that here's a Proof not &longs;o far fetch'd for the A&longs;tronomy of the Planets, the &longs;ame which we u&longs;ed for their having rational Creatures, and enjoying the other Advantages we before talk'd of, which &longs;erves at the &longs;ame time for the Confirmation of our former Conjectures. But if Amazement and Fear at the Eclip&longs;es of the Moon and Sun gave the fir&longs;t occa&longs;ion to the Study of A&longs;tronomy, as probably they did, then it's almo&longs;t impo&longs;&longs;ible that Jupiter and Saturn &longs;hould be without it; the Argument being of much greater force in them, by rea&longs;on of the daily Eclip&longs;es of their Moons, and the frequent ones of the Sun to their Inhabitants. So that if a Per&longs;on di&longs;intere&longs;ted in his Judgment, and equally ignorant of the Affairs of all the Planets, were to give his Opinion in this Matter, I don't doubt he would give the Cau&longs;e for A&longs;tronomy to tho&longs;e two Planets rather than us.
This Suppo&longs;ition of their Knowledge and U&longs;e of A&longs;tronomy in the Planetary Worlds, will afford us many new Conjectures about their manner of Life, and their State as to other things.
And all its &longs;ub&longs;ervient Arts. For, Fir&longs;t: No Ob&longs;ervations of the Stars that are nece&longs;&longs;ary to the Knowledge of their Motions, can be made without In&longs;truments; nor can the&longs;e be made without Metal, Wood, or &longs;ome &longs;uch &longs;olid Body. Here's a nece&longs;&longs;ity of allowing them the Carpenters Tools, the Saw, the Ax, the Plane, the Mallet, the File: and the making of the&longs;e requires the U&longs;e of Iron, or &longs;ome equally hard Metal. Geometry and Arithmetick: Again, the&longs;e In&longs;truments can't be without a Circle divided into equal Parts, or a &longs;trait Line into unequal. Here's a nece&longs;&longs;ity for introducing Geometry and Arithmetick. Then the Nece&longs;&longs;ity And Writing. in &longs;uch Ob&longs;ervations of marking down the Epochas or Accounts of Time, and of tran&longs;mitting them to Po&longs;terity, will force us to grant them the Art of Writing; perhaps very different from ours which is commonly u&longs;ed, but I dare affirm not more ingenious
or ea&longs;y. For how much more ready and expeditious is our Way, than by that multitude of Characters u&longs;ed in China; and how va&longs;tly preferable to Knots tied in Cords, or the Pictures in u&longs;e among the barbarous People of Mexico and Peru? There's no Nation in the World but has &longs;ome way or other of writing or marking down their Thoughts: So that it's no wonder if the Planetary Inhabitants have been taught it by that great School-mi&longs;tre&longs;s Nece&longs;&longs;ity, and apply it to the Study of A&longs;tronomy and other Sciences. In A&longs;tronomical Matters the Nece&longs;&longs;ity of it is moreover apparent from hence, that the Motion of the Stars is as 'twere to be fancied and gue&longs;s'd at in different Sy&longs;tems, and the&longs;e Sy&longs;tems to be continually improved and corrected, as later and more exact Ob&longs;ervations &longs;hall convince the old ones of Faults: all which can never be deliver'd down to &longs;ucceeding Generations, unle&longs;s we make u&longs;e of Letters and Figures.
But after all the&longs;e large and liberal Allowances to Them, they will &longs;till
be behind-hand with us. For we have &longs;o certain a Knowledge of the true And Opticks. Sy&longs;tem and Frame of the Univer&longs;e; we have &longs;o admirable an Invention of Tele&longs;copes to help our failing Eye-&longs;ight in the view of the Bigne&longs;s and different Forms of the Planetary Bodies, in the di&longs;covery of the Mountains, and the Shadows of them on the Surface of the Moon, in the bringing to light an innumerable multitude of Stars otherwi&longs;e invi&longs;ible, that we mu&longs;t nece&longs;&longs;arily be far their Ma&longs;ters in that Knowledge. Hence it is almo&longs;t nece&longs;&longs;ary (except we have a Mind to flatter and complement our &longs;elves as the only People that have the Advantage of &longs;uch excellent Inventions) either to allow the Planetary Inhabitants &longs;uch &longs;harp Eyes as not to need them, or el&longs;e the u&longs;e of Gla&longs;&longs;es to help the Deficiency of their Sight. And yet I dare not a&longs;&longs;ert this, le&longs;t any one &longs;hould be &longs;o di&longs;turbed at the Extravagancy of &longs;uch an Opinion, as to take the mea&longs;ure of my other Conjectures by it, and hi&longs;s them all off, upon the account of this alone.
The&longs;e Sciences not contrary to Nature. But &longs;ome Body may perhaps object, and that not without rea&longs;on at fir&longs;t &longs;ight, that the Planetary Inhabitants it's likely are de&longs;titute of all refined Knowledge, ju&longs;t as the Americans were before they had Commerce with the Europeans. For if one con&longs;iders the Ignorance of tho&longs;e Nations, and of others in A&longs;ia and Africa equally barbarous, it will appear as if the main De&longs;ign of the Creator in placing Men upon the Earth was that they might live, and, in a ju&longs;t &longs;en&longs;e of all the Ble&longs;&longs;ings and Plea&longs;ure they enjoy, wor&longs;hip the Fountain of their Happine&longs;s; but that &longs;ome few went beyond the Bounds of Nature in their Enquiries after Knowledge. There does not want an An&longs;wer to the&longs;e Men. For God could not but fore&longs;ee the Advances Men would make, in their enquiring into the Heavenly Bodies: that they would di&longs;cover Arts u&longs;eful and advantageous to Life: that they would cro&longs;s the Seas, and dig up the Bowels of the Earth. Nothing of all this could happen contrary to the Mind and Knowledge of the Infinite Author of all Things. And if
he fore&longs;aw the&longs;e Things would be, he &longs;o appointed and de&longs;tin'd them to humane kind. And the Studies of Arts and Sciences cannot be &longs;aid to be contrary to Nature, &longs;ince in the &longs;earch thereof they are employ'd: e&longs;pecially if we con&longs;ider how great the natural, de&longs;ire and love of Knowledge, rooted in all Men is. For it's impo&longs;&longs;ible this &longs;hould have been given them upon no De&longs;ign or Account. But they will urge, that if &longs;uch a Knowledge is natural, if we were born for it, why are there &longs;o very few, e&longs;pecially in A&longs;tronomy, that pro&longs;ecute the&longs;e Studies? For Europe is the only Quarter of the Earth in which there have been any Advancements made in A&longs;tronomy. And as for the Judicial A&longs;trology, which pretends to foretel what is to come, it is &longs;uch a wretched and oftentimes mi&longs;chievous piece of Madne&longs;s, that I do not think it ought to be &longs;o much as named here. And even in Europe, not one in a hundred Thou&longs;and meddles with the&longs;e Studies. Be&longs;ides, its Original and Ri&longs;e is &longs;o late, that many Ages were pa&longs;t before
the very fir&longs;t Rudiments of A&longs;tronomy or Geometry (which is nece&longs;&longs;ary to the learning of it) were known. For every Body is acquainted almo&longs;t with its fir&longs;t Beginnings in Egypt and Greece. Add to this, that 'tis not yet above four&longs;core Years &longs;ince the bungling Epicycles were di&longs;carded, and the true and ea&longs;y plain Motion of the Planets was di&longs;covered. For the Satisfaction of the&longs;e Scruples, to what we &longs;aid before, concerning the Fore-knowledge of God, may be added this; That God never de&longs;igned we &longs;hould come into the World A&longs;tronomers or Philo&longs;ophers; the&longs;e Arts are not infu&longs;ed into us at our Birth, but were ordered, in long Tracts of Time, by degrees to be the Rewards and Re&longs;ult of laborious Diligence; e&longs;pecially tho&longs;e Sciences which are now in debate, are &longs;o much the more difficult and ab&longs;tru&longs;e, that their late Invention and &longs;low Progre&longs;s are &longs;o far from being a Wonder, that it is rather &longs;trange they were ever di&longs;cover'd at all. There are but few, I acknowledge one or two perhaps in an Age, that pur&longs;ue them,
or think them their Bu&longs;ine&longs;s: but their Number will be very con&longs;iderable if we take in tho&longs;e that have lived in all the Ages in which A&longs;tronomy hath flouri&longs;hed: and no Body can deny them that Happine&longs;s and Contentment which they have pretended to above all others. In fine, it was &longs;ufficient that &longs;o &longs;mall a Number &longs;hould make it their Study, &longs;o that the Profit and Advantage of their Inventions might but &longs;pread it &longs;elf over all the World. Since then the Inhabitants of this Earth, let them be never &longs;o few, have had Parts and Genius &longs;ufficient for the Attainment of this Knowledge; and there's no rea&longs;on to think the Planetary Inhabitants le&longs;s ingenious or happy than our &longs;elves; we have gain'd our Point, and 'tis probable that they are as skilful A&longs;tronomers as we can pretend to be. So that now we may venture to deduce &longs;ome Con&longs;equences from &longs;uch a Suppo&longs;ition.
We have before &longs;how'd the nece&longs;&longs;ary Dependence and Connexion, not only of Geometry and Arithmetick, but of Mechanical Arts and In&longs;truments with this Science. This leads
us naturally to the Enquiry how they can u&longs;e the&longs;e In&longs;truments and Engines for the Ob&longs;ervation of the Stars, how they can write down &longs;uch their Ob&longs;ervations, and perform other Things which we do with our Hands. So that we mu&longs;t nece&longs;&longs;arily give them They have Hands. Hands, or &longs;ome other Member, as convenient for all those U&longs;es, in&longs;tead of them. One of the ancient Philo&longs;ophers laid &longs;uch Stre&longs;s upon the U&longs;e and Conveniency of the Hands, that he made no &longs;cruple to affirm, they were the Cau&longs;e and Foundation of all our Knowledge. By which, I &longs;uppo&longs;e, he meant no more, than that without their Help and A&longs;&longs;i&longs;tance Men could never arrive to the Improvement of their Minds in natural Knowledge: And indeed not without Rea&longs;on. For &longs;uppo&longs;e in&longs;tead of them they had had Hoofs like Hor&longs;es or Bullocks given them, they might have laid indeed the Model and De&longs;ign of Cities and Hou&longs;es in their Head, but they would never have been able to have built them. They would have had no Subject of Di&longs;cour&longs;e but what belong'd to their
Victuals, Marriages, or Self-pre&longs;ervation. They would have been void of all Knowledge and Memory, and indeed would have been but one degree di&longs;tant from brute Bea&longs;ts. What could we invent or imagine that could be &longs;o exactly accommodated to all the de&longs;ign'd U&longs;es as the Hands are? Elephants can lay hold of, or throw any thing with their Probo&longs;cis, can take up even the &longs;malle&longs;t Things from the Ground, and can perform &longs;uch &longs;urpri&longs;ing Things with it, that it has not very improperly been call'd their Hand, tho' indeed it is nothing but a No&longs;e &longs;omewhat longer than ordinary. Nor do Birds &longs;how le&longs;s Art and De&longs;ign in the U&longs;e of their Bills in the picking up their Meat, and the wonderful Compo&longs;ure of their Ne&longs;ts. But all this is nothing to tho&longs;e Conveniences the Hand is &longs;o admirably &longs;uited to; nothing to that amazing Contrivance in its Capacity of being &longs;tretched, or contracted, or turned to any Part as Occa&longs;ion &longs;hall require. And then, to pa&longs;s by that nice Sen&longs;e that the Ends of the Fingers are endued with, even to the feeling and
di&longs;tingui&longs;hing mo&longs;t &longs;orts of Bodies in the Dark, what Wi&longs;dom and Art is &longs;how'd in the Di&longs;po&longs;ition of the Thumb and Fingers, &longs;o as to take up or keep fa&longs;t hold of any Thing we plea&longs;e? Either then the Planetary Inhabitants mu&longs;t have Hands, or &longs;omewhat equally convenient, which it is not ea&longs;y to conceive; or el&longs;e we mu&longs;t &longs;ay that Nature has been kinder not only to us, but even to Squirrels and Monkeys than them.
And Feet. That they have Feet al&longs;o &longs;carce any one can doubt, that does but con&longs;ider what we &longs;aid but ju&longs;t now of Animals different Ways of going along, which it's hard to imagine can be perform'd any other ways than what we there recounted. And of all tho&longs;e, there's none can agree &longs;o well with the &longs;tate of the Planetary Inhabitants, as that that we here make u&longs;e of. Except (what is not very probable, if they live in Society, as I &longs;hall &longs;how they do) they have found out the Art of flying in &longs;ome of tho&longs;e Worlds.
That they are upright. The Stature and Shape of Men here does &longs;how forth the Divine Providence
&longs;o much in its being &longs;o fitly adapted to its de&longs;ign'd U&longs;es, that it is not without rea&longs;on that all the Philo&longs;ophers have taken notice of it, nor without Probability that the Planetary Inhabitants have their Eyes and Countenance upright, like us, for the more convenient and ea&longs;y Contemplation and Ob&longs;ervations of the Stars. For if the Wi&longs;dom of the Creator is &longs;o ob&longs;ervable, &longs;o Prai&longs;e-worthy in the Po&longs;ition of the other Members; in the convenient Situation of the Eyes, as Watches in the higher Region of the Body; in the removing of the more uncomely Parts out of &longs;ight as 'twere, we cannot but think he has almo&longs;t ob&longs;erved the &longs;ame Method in the Bodies of tho&longs;e remote Inhabitants. Nor It follows not therefore that they have the &longs;ame Shape with us. does it follow from hence that they mu&longs;t be of the &longs;ame Shape with us. For there is &longs;uch an infinite po&longs;&longs;ible variety of Figures to be imagined, that both the Structure of their whole Bodies, and every part of them, both out&longs;ide and in&longs;ide, may be quite different from ours. How warmly and conveniently are &longs;ome Creatures cloth'd with
Wool, and how finely are others decked and adorn'd with Feathers? Perhaps among the rational Creatures in the Planets there may &longs;ome &longs;uch di&longs;tinction be ob&longs;erv'd in their Garb and Covering; a Thing in which Bea&longs;ts &longs;eem to excel Men in here. Unle&longs;s perhaps Men are born naked, for this rea&longs;on to put them upon employing and exerci&longs;ing their Wits, in the inventing and making that Attire that Nature had made nece&longs;&longs;ary for them. And 'tis this Nece&longs;&longs;ity that has been the greate&longs;t, if not only occa&longs;ion of all the Trade and Commerce, of all the Mechanical Inventions and Di&longs;coveries that we are Ma&longs;ters of. Be&longs;ides, Nature might have another great Conveniency in her Eye, by bringing Men into the World naked, namely, that they might accommodate them&longs;elves to all places of the World, and go thicker or thinner cloth'd, according as the Sea&longs;on and Climate they liv'd in requir'd. There may &longs;till be conceived a greater difference between us and the Inhabitants of the Planets; for there are &longs;ome &longs;ort of Animals, &longs;uch
as Oy&longs;ters, Lob&longs;ters, and Crab-fi&longs;h, who&longs;e Fle&longs;h is on the in&longs;ide of their Bones as 'twere. But that which hinders me from a&longs;cribing &longs;uch a kind of Frame and Compo&longs;ition to the Planetary Inhabitants, is that Nature &longs;eems to have done it only in a few of the meane&longs;t Sort of Creatures, and that hereby they would be deprived of that quick ea&longs;y motion of their Hands and Fingers, which is &longs;o u&longs;eful and nece&longs;&longs;ary to them, otherwi&longs;e I &longs;hould not be much affected with the odd Shape and Figure.
A rational Soul may inhabit another Shape than ours. For 'tis a very ridiculous Opinion, that the common People have got, that 'tis impo&longs;&longs;ible a rational Soul &longs;hould dwell in any other Shape than ours. And yet as &longs;illy as 'tis, it has been the occa&longs;ion of many Philo&longs;ophers allowing the Gods no other Shape; nay, the Foundation of a Sect among the Chri&longs;tians, that from hence have the Name of Anthropomorphites. This can proceed from nothing but the Weakne&longs;s, Ignorance, and Prejudice of Men; the &longs;ame as that other concerning humane Shape, that it is
the hand&longs;ome&longs;t and mo&longs;t excellent of all others, when indeed it's nothing but a being accu&longs;tomed to that Figure that makes us think &longs;o, and a Conceit that we and all other Animals naturally have, that no Shape or Colour can be &longs;o good as our own. Yet &longs;o powerful are the&longs;e, that were we to meet with a Creature of a much different Shape from Man, with Rea&longs;on and Speech, we &longs;hould be much &longs;urpri&longs;ed and &longs;hocked at the Sight. For if we try to imagine or paint a Creature like a Man in every Thing el&longs;e, but that has a Neck four times as long, and great round Eyes five or &longs;ix times as big, and farther di&longs;tant, we cannot look upon't without the utmo&longs;t Aver&longs;ion, altho' at the &longs;ame time we can give no account of our Di&longs;like.
The Planetarians not le&longs;s than we. When I ju&longs;t now mentioned the Stature of the Planetary Inhabitants, I hinted that 'twas improbable they &longs;hould be le&longs;s than we are. For it's likely, that as our Bodies are made in &longs;uch a proportion to our Earth, as to render us capable of travelling about it, and making Ob&longs;ervations
upon its Bulk and Figure, the &longs;ame Order is ob&longs;erv'd in the Inhabitants of the other Planets, unle&longs;s in this Particular al&longs;o, which is very con&longs;iderable, we would prefer our &longs;elves to all others. Then &longs;eeing we have before allow'd them A&longs;tronomy and Ob&longs;ervations, we mu&longs;t give them Bodies and Strength &longs;ufficient for the ruling their In&longs;truments, and the erecting their Tubes and Engines. And for this the larger they are the better. For if we &longs;hould &longs;uppo&longs;e them Dwarfs not above the Bigne&longs;s of Rats or Mice, they could neither make &longs;uch Ob&longs;ervations as are requi&longs;ite; nor &longs;uch In&longs;truments as are nece&longs;&longs;ary to tho&longs;e Ob&longs;ervations. Therefore we mu&longs;t &longs;uppo&longs;e them larger than, or at lea&longs;t equal to, our &longs;elves, e&longs;pecially in Jupiter and Saturn, which are &longs;o va&longs;tly bigger than the Planet which we inhabit.
They live in Society. A&longs;tronomy, we &longs;aid before, could never &longs;ub&longs;i&longs;t without the writing down the Ob&longs;ervations: Nor could the Art of Writing (any more than the Arts of Carpenters and Founders) ever be found out except in a Society
of rea&longs;onable Creatures, where the Nece&longs;&longs;ities of Life forc'd them upon Invention: So that it follows from hence, (as was before &longs;aid) that the Planetary Inhabitants mu&longs;t in this be like us, that they maintain a Society and Fellow&longs;hip with, and afford mutual A&longs;&longs;i&longs;tances and Helps to one another. Hereupon we mu&longs;t allow them a &longs;ettled, not a wandring Scythian way of living, as more convenient for Men in &longs;uch Circum&longs;tances. But what follows from hence? Mu&longs;t they not have every thing el&longs;e proper for &longs;uch a manner of living granted them too? Mu&longs;t they not have their Governours, Hou&longs;es, Cities, Trade and Bartering? Why &longs;hould they not, when even the barbarous People of America and other Places were at their fir&longs;t Di&longs;covery found to have &longs;omewhat of that nature in u&longs;e among them. I don't &longs;ay, that Things mu&longs;t be the &longs;ame there as they are here. We have many that may very well be &longs;pared among rational Creatures, and were de&longs;ign'd only for the pre&longs;ervation of Society from all Injury, and for the curbing of tho&longs;e
Men who make an ill u&longs;e of their Rea&longs;on to the Detriment of others. Perhaps in the Planets they have &longs;uch plenty and affluence of all good Things, as they neither need or de&longs;ire to &longs;teal from one another; perhaps they may be &longs;o ju&longs;t and good as to be at perpetual Peace, and never to lie in wait for, or take away the Life of their Neighbour: perhaps they may not know what Anger or Hatred are; and if &longs;o, they mu&longs;t be much happier than we. But it's more likely they have &longs;uch a mixture of Good with Bad, of Wi&longs;e with Fools, of War with Peace, and want not that School-mi&longs;tre&longs;s of Arts Poverty. For, as was before &longs;hown, &longs;ome good u&longs;e may be made of the&longs;e things, but if not, there is no Rea&longs;on why we &longs;hould prefer their Condition to our own.
They enjoy the Plea&longs;ures of Society. What I am now going to &longs;ay may &longs;eem &longs;omewhat more bold, and yet is not le&longs;s likely than the former. For if the&longs;e Nations in the Planets live in Society, as I have pretty well &longs;how'd they do, 'tis &longs;omewhat more than probable that they enjoy not only the
Profit, but the Plea&longs;ures ari&longs;ing from Society: &longs;uch as Conver&longs;ation, Amours, Je&longs;ting, and Shews. Otherwi&longs;e we &longs;hould make them live without Diver&longs;ion or Merriment; we &longs;hould deprive them of the great Sweetne&longs;s of Life, which it can't well be without, and give our &longs;elves &longs;uch an Advantage over them as Rea&longs;on will by no means admit of.
But to proceed to a farther Enquiry into their Bu&longs;ine&longs;s and Employment, let's con&longs;ider what we have not yet mention'd, wherein they may bear any Likene&longs;s to us. And fir&longs;t we have good Rea&longs;on to believe they build them&longs;elves Hou&longs;es, becau&longs;e we are &longs;ure they are not without their Showers. For in Jupiter have been ob&longs;erved Clouds, big no doubt with Vapours and Water, which hath been proved by many other Arguments, not to be wanting in that Planet. They have Rain then, for otherwi&longs;e how could all the Vapours drawn up by the Heat of the Sun be di&longs;po&longs;ed of? And Winds, for they are cau&longs;ed only by Vapours di&longs;&longs;olved by Heat, and it's
plain that they blow in Jupiter by the continual Motion and Variety of the They have Hou&longs;es to &longs;ecure 'em from Weather. Clouds about him. To protect them&longs;elves from the&longs;e, and that they may pa&longs;s their Nights in Quiet and Safety, they mu&longs;t build them&longs;elves Tents or Huts, or live in Holes of the Earth. But why may we not &longs;uppo&longs;e the Planetary Inhabitants to be as good Architects, have as noble Hou&longs;es, and as &longs;tately Palaces as our &longs;elves? Unle&longs;s we think that every Thing which belongs to our &longs;elves is the mo&longs;t beautiful and perfect that can be. And who are we, but a few that live in a little Corner of the World, upon a Ball ten Thou&longs;and times le&longs;s than Jupiter or Saturn? And yet we mu&longs;t be the only skilful People at Building; and all others mu&longs;t be our Inferiours in the Knowledge of uniform Symetry; and not be able to rai&longs;e Towers and Pyramids as high, magnificent, and beautiful, as our &longs;elves. For my part, I &longs;ee no rea&longs;on why they may not be as great Ma&longs;ters as we are, and have the U&longs;e of all tho&longs;e Arts &longs;ub&longs;ervient to it, as Stone-cutting and Brick-making,
and what&longs;oever el&longs;e is nece&longs;&longs;ary for it, as Iron, Lead and Gla&longs;s; or ornamental to it, as Gilding and Picture.
If their Globe is divided like ours, into Sea and Land, as it's evident it is (el&longs;e whence could all tho&longs;e Vapours in Jupiter proceed?) we have great Rea&longs;on to allow them the Art of Navigation, and not vainly ingro&longs;s &longs;o great, &longs;o u&longs;eful a Thing to our &longs;elves. E&longs;pecially con&longs;idering the great Advantages Jupiter and Saturn have for Sailing, in having &longs;o many Moons to direct their Cour&longs;e, by who&longs;e Guidance they may attain ea&longs;ily to the Knowledge that we are not Ma&longs;ters of, of the Longitude of Places. And what a Multitude of other Things follow from this Allowance? If they have Ships, they mu&longs;t have Sails and Anchors, Ropes, Pullies, and Rudders, which are of particular U&longs;e in directing a Ship's Cour&longs;e again&longs;t the Wind, and in &longs;ailing different Ways with the &longs;ame Gale. And perhaps they may not be without the U&longs;e of the Compa&longs;s too, for the magnetical Matter, which continually pa&longs;&longs;es thro' the Pores of our Earth,
is of &longs;uch a Nature, that it's very probable the Planets have &longs;omething like They have Navigation, and all Arts &longs;ub&longs;ervient. it. But Geometry &longs;tands in no need of being prov'd after this manner. Nor doth it want A&longs;&longs;i&longs;tance from other Arts which depend upon it, but we may have a nearer and &longs;horter A&longs;&longs;urance of their not being without it in tho&longs;e Earths. For that Science is of &longs;uch &longs;ingular Worth and Dignity, &longs;o peculiarly imploys the Under&longs;tanding, and gives it &longs;uch a full Comprehen&longs;ion and infallible As Geometry. certainty of Truth, as no other Knowledge can pretend to: it is moreover of &longs;uch a Nature, that its Principles and Foundations mu&longs;t be &longs;o immutably the &longs;ame in all Times and Places, that we cannot without Inju&longs;tice pretend to monopolize it, and rob the re&longs;t of the Univer&longs;e of &longs;uch an incomparable Study. Nay Nature it &longs;elf invites us to be Geometricians; it pre&longs;ents us with Geometrical
Figures, with Circles and Squares, with Triangles, Polygones, and Spheres, and propo&longs;es them as it were to our Con&longs;ideration and Study, which ab&longs;tracting from its U&longs;efulne&longs;s, is mo&longs;t delightful and ravi&longs;hing. Who can read Euclid, or Apollonius, about the Circle, without Admiration? Or Archimedes of the Surface of the Sphere, and Quadrature of the Parabola without Amazement? or con&longs;ider the late ingenious Di&longs;coveries of the Moderns with Boldne&longs;s and Unconcernedne&longs;s? And all the&longs;e Truths are as naked and open, and depend upon the &longs;ame plain Principles and Axioms in Jupiter and Saturn as here, which makes it not improbable that there are in the Planets &longs;ome who partake with us in the&longs;e delightful and plea&longs;ant Studies. But what's the greate&longs;t Argument with me, that there are &longs;uch, is their U&longs;e, I had almo&longs;t &longs;aid Nece&longs;&longs;ity, in mo&longs;t Affairs of humane Life. Now we are got thus far, what if we &longs;hould venture &longs;omewhat farther, and &longs;ay, that they have our Inventions of the Tables of Sines, of Logarithms, and
Algebra? I know it would &longs;ound very odd, and perhaps a little ridiculous, and yet there's no rea&longs;on but the thinking our &longs;elves better than all the World, to hinder them from being as happy in their Di&longs;coveries, and as ingenious in their Inventions as we our &longs;elves are.
They have Mu&longs;ick. It's the &longs;ame with Mu&longs;ick as with Geometry, it's every where immutably the &longs;ame, and always will be &longs;o. For all Harmony con&longs;i&longs;ts in Concord, and Concord is all the World over fix'd according to the &longs;ame invariable Mea&longs;ure and Proportion. So that in all Nations the Difference and Di&longs;tance of Notes is the &longs;ame, whether they be in a continued gradual Progre&longs;&longs;ion, or the Voice makes skips over one to the next. Nay very credible Authors report, that there's a &longs;ort of Bird in America, that can plainly &longs;ing in order &longs;ix mu&longs;ical Notes: Whence it follows, that the Laws of Mu&longs;ick are unchangeably fix'd by Nature, and therefore the &longs;ame Rea&longs;on holds for their Mu&longs;ick, as we e'en now &longs;hewed for their Geometry. For why, &longs;uppo&longs;ing other
Nations and Creatures, endued with Rea&longs;on and Sen&longs;e as well as we, &longs;hould not they reap the Plea&longs;ures ari&longs;ing from the&longs;e Sen&longs;es as well as we too? I don't know what Effect this Argument, from the immutable Nature of the&longs;e Arts, may have upon the Minds of others; I think it no incon&longs;iderable or contemptible one, but of as great Strength as that which I made u&longs;e of above to prove that the Planetary Inhabitants had the Sen&longs;e of Seeing.
But if they take delight in Harmony, there is no doubt but that they have invented Mu&longs;ical In&longs;truments. For they could &longs;carce help lighting upon &longs;ome or other by chance; the Sound of a tight String, the Noi&longs;e of the Winds, or the whi&longs;tling of Reeds, might have given them the hint. From the&longs;e &longs;mall Beginnings they perhaps, as well as we, have advanced by degrees to the U&longs;e of the Lute, Harp, Flute, and many &longs;tring'd In&longs;truments. But altho' the Tones are certain and determinate, yet we find among different Nations a quite different manner and rule for Singing; as
formerly among the Dorians, Phrygians, and Lydians, and in our Time among the French, Italians, and Per&longs;ians. In like manner it may &longs;o happen, that the Mu&longs;ick of the Inhabitants of the Planets may widely differ from all the&longs;e, and yet be very good. But why we &longs;hould look upon their Mu&longs;ick to be wor&longs;e than ours, there's no rea&longs;on can be given; neither can we well pre&longs;ume that they want the U&longs;e of Hal&longs;-Notes and Quarter-Notes, &longs;eeing the Invention of Hal&longs;-Notes is &longs;o obvious, and the U&longs;e of them &longs;o agreeable to Nature. Nay, to go a Step farther, what if they &longs;hould excel us in the Theory and practick part of Mu&longs;ick, and outdo us in Con&longs;orts of vocal and in&longs;trumental Mu&longs;ick, &longs;o artificially compos'd, that they &longs;hew their Skill by the Mixtures of Di&longs;cords and Concords? and of this la&longs;t &longs;ort 'tis very likely the 5th and 3d are in u&longs;e with them.
This is a very bold A&longs;&longs;ertion, but it may be true for ought we know, and the Inhabitants of the Planets may po&longs;&longs;ibly have a greater in&longs;ight into the Theory of Mu&longs;ick than has yet been
di&longs;cover'd among us. For if you ask any of our Mu&longs;icians, why two or more perfect Fifths cannot be u&longs;ed regularly in Compo&longs;ition; &longs;ome &longs;ay 'tis to avoid that Sweetne&longs;s and Lu&longs;hiou&longs;ne&longs;s which ari&longs;es from the Repetition of this plea&longs;ing Chord. Others &longs;ay, this mu&longs;t be avoided for the &longs;ake of that Variety of Chords that are requi&longs;ite to make a good Compo&longs;ition; and the&longs;e Rea&longs;ons are brought by Cartes and others. But an Inhabitant of Jupiter or Venus will perhaps give you a better Rea&longs;on for this, viz. becau&longs;e when you pa&longs;s from one perfect Fifth to another, there is &longs;uch a Change made as immediately alters your Key, you are got into a new Key before the Ear is prepared for it, and the more perfect Chords you u&longs;e of the &longs;ame kind in Con&longs;ecution, by &longs;o much the more you offend the Ear by the&longs;e abrupt Changes.
Again, one of the&longs;e Inhabitants perhaps can &longs;how how it comes about, that in a Song of one or more Parts, the Key cannot be kept &longs;o well in the &longs;ame agreeable Tenour, unle&longs;s the intermediate Clo&longs;es and Intervals be &longs;o temper'd,
as to vary from their u&longs;ual Proportions, and thereby to bear a little this way or that, in order to regulate the Scale. And why this Temperature is be&longs;t in the Sy&longs;tem of the Strings, when out of the Fifth the fourth Part of a Comma is u&longs;ually cut off; This &longs;ame thing I have formerly &longs;hew'd at large.
But for the regulating the Tone of the Voice (as I before hinted) that may admit of a more ea&longs;y proof, and we &longs;hall give you an E&longs;&longs;ay of it, &longs;ince I have mentioned a thing that is not mere Imagination only: I &longs;ay therefore, if any Per&longs;on &longs;trike tho&longs;e Sounds which the Mu&longs;icians di&longs;tingui&longs;h by the&longs;e Letters, C, F, D, G, C, by the&longs;e agreeable Intervals, altogether perfect, interchangeable, a&longs;cending and de&longs;cending with the Voice: Now this latter &longs;ound C will be one Comma, or very &longs;mall portion lower than the fir&longs;t &longs;ounding of C. Becau&longs;e of the&longs;e perfect Intervals, which are as 4 to 3, 5 to 6, 4 to 3, 2 to 3, an account is made in &longs;uch a Proportion, as 160 to 162. that is, as 80 to 81, which is what they call a Comma. So that if the &longs;ame Sound
&longs;hould be repeated nine times, the Voice would fall near the Matter a greater Tone, who&longs;e proportion is as 8 to 9. But this the Sen&longs;e of the Ears by no means endures, but remembers the fir&longs;t Tone, and returns to it again. Therefore we are compell'd to u&longs;e an occult Temperament, and to &longs;ing the&longs;e imperfect Intervals, from doing which le&longs;s Offence ari&longs;es. And for the mo&longs;t part, all Singing wants this Temperament, as may be collected by the afore&longs;aid Computations. And the&longs;e things we have offer'd to tho&longs;e that have &longs;ome Knowledge in Geometry.
We have &longs;poke of the&longs;e Arts and Inventions, which it is very probable the Inhabitants of the Planets partake of in common with us, be&longs;ides which it &longs;eems requi&longs;ite to take in many other Things that &longs;erve either for the U&longs;e or Plea&longs;ure of their Lives. But what the&longs;e Things are we &longs;hall the better account for, by laying before us many of tho&longs;e Things which are found among us. I have before mention'd the Variety of Animals and Vegetables, which very much differ from each other,
among which there are &longs;ome that differ but little; and I have &longs;aid, that there are no le&longs;s differences in the&longs;e Things in the Planetary Worlds.
I &longs;hall now take a &longs;hort view of the Benefits we receive both from tho&longs;e Herbs and Animals, and &longs;ee whether we may not with very good rea&longs;on conclude that the Planetary Inhabitants reap as great and as many from tho&longs;e that their Countries afford them.
And here it may be worth our while to take a Review of the Variety and Multitude of our Riches. For Trees and Herbs do not only &longs;erve us for Food, they in their delicious Fruits, the&longs;e in their Seeds, Leaves and Roots; but Herbs moreover furni&longs;h us with Phy&longs;ick, and Trees with Timber for our Hou&longs;es and Ships. Of Hemp or Matweed we twi&longs;t our &longs;elves Thread and &longs;mall Ropes, the former of which we employ in Sails and Nets, the latter in making larger Ropes for Ma&longs;ts and Anchors. In which we have &longs;o excellent, &longs;o u&longs;eful an Invention of Wheels, that I can't &longs;uppo&longs;e the Planets to enjoy Society and all its Con&longs;equences, and be without them. Whether they are Pythagoreans there, or feed upon Fle&longs;h as we do, I dare not affirm any Thing. Tho' it &longs;eems to be allowed Men to feed upon what&longs;oever may afford them Nouri&longs;hment, either on Land, or in
Water, upon Herbs, and Pomes, Milk, Eggs, Honey, Fi&longs;h, and no le&longs;s upon the Fle&longs;h of many Birds and Bea&longs;ts. But it is a &longs;urpri&longs;ing thing! that a rational Creature &longs;hould live upon the Ruin and De&longs;truction of &longs;uch a number of other his Fellow-Creatures! very In&longs;ects, who can but admire the &longs;ix-corner'd Cells of the Bees, or the artificial Web of a Spider, or the fine Bag of a Silk-worm, which la&longs;t affords us, with the Help of incredible Indu&longs;try, even Shiploads of &longs;oft delicate Clothing. This is a &longs;hort Summary of tho&longs;e many profitable Advantages the animal and herbal World &longs;erve us with.
But this is not all. The Bowels of the Earth likewi&longs;e contribute much to Man's Happine&longs;s. For what Art and Cunning does he employ in finding, in digging, in trying Metals, and in melting, refining, and tempering them? And from Metals. What Skill and Nicety in beating, drawing or di&longs;&longs;olving Gold, &longs;o as with incon&longs;iderable Changes to make every Thing he plea&longs;es put on that noble Lu&longs;tre? Of how many and admirable U&longs;es is Iron? and how ignorant in all Mechanical Knowledge were tho&longs;e Nations that were not acquainted with it, &longs;o as to have no other Arms but Bows, Clubs, and Spears, made of Wood. There's one Thing indeed we have, which it's a Que&longs;tion whether it has
done more harm or good, and that is Gun-powder made of Nitre and Brim&longs;tone. At fir&longs;t indeed it &longs;eem'd as if we had got a more &longs;ecure Defen&longs;e than former Ages again&longs;t all A&longs;&longs;aults, and could ea&longs;ily guard our Towns, by the wonderful Strength of that Invention, again&longs;t all ho&longs;tile Inva&longs;ions: but now we find it has rather encouraged them, and at the &longs;ame time been no &longs;mall Occa&longs;ion of the Decay of Valour, by rendring it and Strength almo&longs;t u&longs;ele&longs;s in War. Had the Grecian Emperor who &longs;aid, Virtue was ruin'd only when Slings and Rams fir&longs;t came into u&longs;e, liv'd in our Days, he might well have complain'd; e&longs;pecially of Bombs, again&longs;t which neither Art nor Nature is of &longs;ufficient Proof: but which lays every Thing, Ca&longs;tles and Towers, be they never &longs;o &longs;trong, even with the Ground. If for nothing el&longs;e, yet upon this one account, I think we had better have been without the Di&longs;covery. Yet, when we were talking of our Di&longs;coveries, it was not to be pa&longs;s'd over, for the Planets too may have their mi&longs;chievous as well as u&longs;eful Inventions.
We are happier in the U&longs;es for which the Air and Water &longs;erves us; both of which helps us in our Navigation, and furni&longs;hes us with a Strength &longs;ufficient, without any Labour of our own, to turn round our Mills and Engines; Things which are of u&longs;e to us in &longs;o many different Employments. For with them we grind our Corn, and &longs;queeze out our Oil; with them we cut Wood, and mill Cloth, and with them we beat our Stuff for Paper. An incomparable Invention! Where the na&longs;tie&longs;t u&longs;ele&longs;s Scraps of Linen are made to produce fine white Sheets. To the&longs;e we may add the late di&longs;covery of Printing, which not only pre&longs;erves from Death Arts and Knowledge, but makes them much ea&longs;ier to be attained than before. Nor mu&longs;t we forget the Arts of Engraving and Painting, which from mean Beginnings have improved to that Excellence, that nothing that ever &longs;prung from the Wit of Man can claim Pre-eminence to them. Nor is the way of melting and blowing Gla&longs;&longs;es, and of poli&longs;hing and &longs;preading Quick-&longs;ilver
over Looking-Gla&longs;&longs;es, unworthy of being mentioned, nor above all, the admirable u&longs;es that Gla&longs;&longs;es have been put to in natural Knowledge, &longs;ince the Invention of the Tele&longs;cope and Micro&longs;cope. From the di&longs;coveries of our Age. I might add much here of the late Di&longs;coveries, mo&longs;t of them of this Age, which have been made in all &longs;orts of Natural Knowledge as well as in Geometry and A&longs;tronomy, as of the Weight and Spring of the Air, of the Chymical Experiments that have &longs;hown us a way of making Liquors that &longs;hall &longs;hine in the Dark, and with gentle moving &longs;hall burn of them&longs;elves. The Planets have, tho' not the&longs;e &longs;ame, yet as u&longs;eful Inventions. Thus have I put together all the&longs;e late Di&longs;coveries of our Earth: and now, tho' perhaps &longs;ome of them may be common to the Planetary Inhabitants with us, yet that they &longs;hould have all of them is not credible.
